Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story:
I was sitting at the kitchen table, my laptop open, half-listening to the hum of the dishwasher, when my granddaughter slid into the chair beside me. Her eyes were wide, uncertain. “Grandma, how did you know what to do when you started something new?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I could see she needed reassurance, a story, maybe a gentle nudge in the right direction. My heart ached to give her all the wisdom I’d gathered over the years.

But just as I reached for her hand, my phone buzzed urgently. Slack messages piled up: “Production is down. Users can’t log in. Can you look at the code?” My chest tightened. I knew the outage was traced to a bug I’d pushed earlier. The team was waiting for me to fix it—customers were locked out, and every minute counted.

I looked at my granddaughter, her hopefulness, her need for guidance. I looked at my screen, the frantic messages, the responsibility pressing down. Both worlds tugged at me, each expecting me to be fully present, to solve, to comfort. I felt split in two, caught between the wisdom she needed and the crisis only I could resolve.
